intro: Aulomyrcia jequitinhonhensis var. glauca, commonly known as the glaucous aulomyrcia, is a rare shrub native to the Brazilian state of Pará. It is characterized by its grayish-blue foliage, which gives it its common name, and its small, clustered flowers that bloom in the spring. The plant thrives in humid, shaded environments within the Atlantic Forest biome. It has narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a waxy coating. Due to habitat loss, this variety is considered endangered and is of interest to botanists studying plant adaptation and conservation.
